head.title: What's Washing Up on Coasts Can Hurt

hedline.hl1: What's Washing Up on Coasts Can Hurt

block.p: In the summer of 1988, when the sea spewed syringes and sewage onto our nation's shores, ocean dumping was halted. "Sea Dumping Ban: Good Politics, but Not Necessarily Good Policy" (front page, March 22) reports debate on the cost-effectiveness of such measures. Meanwhile, our coasts face assaults from industrial pollutants, fertilizers, eroding soil, acid rain and sewage, plus pesticides and other chemicals, posing enormous long-term health threats.

In the summer of 1988, when the sea spewed syringes and sewage onto our nation's shores, ocean dumping was halted. "Sea Dumping Ban: Good Politics, but Not Necessarily Good Policy" (front page, March 22) reports debate on the cost-effectiveness of such measures. Meanwhile, our coasts face assaults from industrial pollutants, fertilizers, eroding soil, acid rain and sewage, plus pesticides and other chemicals, posing enormous long-term health threats.

Nutrient-rich discharges cause eutrophication or overgrowth of algae. In the last decade, blooms of algae, or "red tides," of increased intensity, duration and extent have been reported worldwide. At the same time:
* Reports of algae-derived paralytic, diarrheic and neurological fish and shellfish poisonings have accelerated.
* Microbiological techniques have detected an algae reservoir for cholera, helping explain arrival and persistence of cholera in the Americas

* Algae mats are snuffing out large shellfish nurseries and coral reefs. In Montauk, L.I.'s Peconic Bay, for example, "brown tide" has crippled the scallop crop and stunted the clams. Health, aquaculture industry and tourism all bear the brunt.

Coastal ecology is being transformed, with alterations to the most ancient food web. The Clinton-Gore Administration must not falter in confronting the rapid pace of environmental change, harnessing strategies from harbor cleanup to climate policies. The costs of business as usual mount. PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D. Cambridge, Mass., March 22, 1993
